segments.text: Could you tell us some things you may remember from the Depression?
Well, honey, of course, it was keener then than it would be now because they'd have so much more help now than they did then.
But during the Depression, Brown was not such a big city.
And she didn't have all of these schools, these wonderful, wonderful educational schools that we have.
I don't know how many we have, but we have a great many because when I came up, there was only one school and one for the Negroes, the blacks, as I'd call them.
But nobody really and truly suffered, but they...
They were deprived of many of their comforts and pleasures for a long time after that, because it takes a long time to accumulate what goes with those floods.
Do you remember anything about the World War I or World War II?
Well, no, except that just like any other town, we had to give up some of our finest boys.
And everybody was patriotic, too.
As long as you could be patriotic, boys were called and they went.
I'd just like to go back a few steps now.
You were telling me about your sister who married a man from here, your father's sister?
Uh-huh.
Do you know how they came to settle in this area?
No, I don't.
You don't?
Where was your family from before they came here?
Arkansas.
My father was born and raised in Arkansas, and my mother was raised, born in Nashville, Tennessee.
So your grandparents came to America?
Yes.
From where?
My great-grandfather.
Oh.
Yes.
Where did he come from?
Huh?
Where did he come from?
Came from Ireland, I think.
But I'm not positive about that.
This book here, I think, will tell it because I've got the, you want to put that in there, don't you?
I have the tree right here and pictures of the, there's the tree right here.
One landed in Pennsylvania, you see.
That's the one I went on the DAR on.
See, it starts from here.
This, I don't know where the original...
what brought P.R.
Smith out here.
But as a young man, he wanted to come.
And his wife came with him, which her name was Nancy, Nanny.
And they called her Nancy.
And she died here.
And her little four-year-old son did also.
And they're buried here in the Brown City Cemetery.
About how big was Bryan as far back as you can remember?
What is it?
About how big was Bryan?
Oh, it was not big at all, honey.
You could walk anywhere you wanted to walk around town.
There was very little going this way at all, man, this way.
They seemed to be going more this way.
More north?
But that was just a few that went that way.
But Brian built, I thought, pretty fast.
We thought we were just as rich as pieces when the iron gin came in.
And that was before my marriage.
The what?
That was before my marriage.
What kind of gin?
In 1900 and more.
Oh.
Okay.
They had a big barbecue, big barbecue over by the Kemp High School.
That's the black...
Thank you.
Thank you.
